It's clearly not a religion since it doesn't have like, membership rituals and holy places and whatnot - all stuff that contributes to the vague meaning of what is a religion.  But a belief system isn't that, it's far more basic and straightforward - a category of your beliefs.  They can be no beliefs, and it's still a category of what your beliefs are (besides which this definition of atheism doesn't necessarily mean 'no beliefs' so long as they aren't god-based ones).  Being as atheism is based entirely upon this categorization of someone's beliefs (for them not to be god-based), what's wrong with calling it a belief system?  What's even the jump to defend against that?  I don't get it.  People seem to react to it like it's some kind of insult or accusation.  This just puzzles me.  It's surely only meant to be a useful way of meaning a rough sum of one's beliefs?  Is there some kind of history here that I'm unaware of, like someone stumbling across a hate word they don't know is a hate word?  Like, how unnecessarily difficult would it make maths if we insisted that nobody could call zero a number?
